workflow.name: Generate images from text with IBM Granite Vision 3.3 2B AI model
workflow.description:
# Generate Images from Text with IBM Granite Vision 3.3 2B AI Model

### üåç **Overview**

This workflow uses the **ibm-granite/granite-vision-3.3-2b** model (hosted on Replicate) to generate AI images. It starts manually, sends a request to the Replicate API, waits for the result, and finally outputs the generated image link.

Think of it as your **AI art assistant** ‚Äî you click once, and it handles the full request/response cycle for image generation.

---

## üü¢ Section 1: Trigger & API Setup

üîó **Nodes:**

* **Manual Trigger** ‚Üí Starts when you click *Execute*.
* **Set API Key** ‚Üí Stores your Replicate API Key safely in the workflow.

üí° **Beginner takeaway:**
This section is like turning the key in the ignition. You start the workflow, and it loads your credentials so you can talk to Replicate‚Äôs API.

üìà **Advantage:**
Keeps your API key stored inside the workflow instead of hard-coding it everywhere.

---

## üü¶ Section 2: Create Prediction

üîó **Nodes:**

* **HTTP Request (Create Prediction)** ‚Üí Sends a request to Replicate with the chosen model (`granite-vision-3.3-2b`) and input parameters (seed, temperature, max\_tokens, etc.).

üí° **Beginner takeaway:**
This is where the workflow actually **asks the AI model to generate an image**.

üìà **Advantage:**
You can tweak parameters like **creativity (temperature)** or **randomness (seed)** to control results.

---

## üü£ Section 3: Polling & Status Check

üîó **Nodes:**

* **Extract Prediction ID (Code)** ‚Üí Saves the unique job ID.
* **Wait (2s)** ‚Üí Pauses before checking status.
* **Check Prediction Status (HTTP Request)** ‚Üí Calls Replicate to see if the image is ready.
* **If Condition (Check If Complete)** ‚Üí

  * ‚úÖ If `status = succeeded` ‚Üí move to result
  * üîÑ Else ‚Üí go back to Wait and check again

üí° **Beginner takeaway:**
Since image generation takes a few seconds, this section keeps **asking the AI ‚Äúare you done yet?‚Äù** until the image is ready.

üìà **Advantage:**
No need to guess ‚Äî the workflow waits automatically and retries until success.

---

## üîµ Section 4: Process Result

üîó **Nodes:**

* **Process Result (Code)** ‚Üí Extracts the final data:

  * ‚úÖ Status
  * ‚úÖ Output image URL
  * ‚úÖ Metrics (time taken, etc.)
  * ‚úÖ Model info

üí° **Beginner takeaway:**
This section **collects the finished image link** and prepares it neatly for you.

üìà **Advantage:**
You get structured output that you can **save, display, or use in another workflow** (like auto-sending images to Slack or saving to Google Drive).

---

## üìä Final Overview Table

| Section              | Nodes                              | Purpose                     | Benefit                     |
| -------------------- | ---------------------------------- | --------------------------- | --------------------------- |
| üü¢ Trigger & Setup   | Manual Trigger, Set API Key        | Start + load credentials    | Secure API key management   |
| üü¶ Create Prediction | HTTP Request                       | Ask AI to generate image    | Control creativity & output |
| üü£ Polling           | Extract ID, Wait, Check Status, If | Repeatedly check job status | Auto-wait until done        |
| üîµ Process Result    | Process Result                     | Extract image + details     | Get clean output for reuse  |

---

## üöÄ Why This Workflow is Useful

* **Automates full API cycle** ‚Üí From request to final image URL
* **Handles delays automatically** ‚Üí Keeps checking until your image is ready
* **Customizable parameters** ‚Üí Adjust creativity, randomness, and token limits
* **Reusable** ‚Üí Connect it to email, Slack, Notion, or storage for instant sharing
* **Beginner-friendly** ‚Üí Just plug in your API key and hit *Execute*

---

Explore more tips and tutorials here:

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
